text:
PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition
Ziyang Zhang1Qizhen Zhang2Jakob Foerster2
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have shown
success in many natural language processing tasks.
Despite rigorous safety alignment processes,
supposedly safety-aligned LLMs like Llama 2
and Claude 2 are still susceptible to jailbreaks,
leading to security risks and abuse of the models.
One option to mitigate such risks is to augment
the LLM with a dedicated “safeguard”, which
checks the LLM’s inputs or outputs for undesired
behaviour. A promising approach is to use
the LLM itself as the safeguard. Nonetheless,
baseline methods, such as prompting the LLM to
self-classify toxic content, demonstrate limited
efficacy. We hypothesise that this is due to
domain shift : the alignment training imparts a
self-censoring behaviour to the model (“Sorry I
can’t do that”), while the self-classify approach
shifts it to a classification format (“Is this
prompt malicious”). In this work, we propose
PARDEN, which avoids this domain shift by
simply asking the model to repeat its own
outputs . PARDEN neither requires finetuning nor
white box access to the model. We empirically
verify the effectiveness of our method and show
that PARDEN significantly outperforms existing
jailbreak detection baselines for Llama-2 and
Claude-2. Code and data are available at
https://github.com/Ed-Zh/PARDEN.
We find that PARDEN is particularly powerful
in the relevant regime of high True Positive Rate
(TPR) and low False Positive Rate (FPR). For
instance, for Llama2-7B, at TPR equal to 90%,
PARDEN accomplishes a roughly 11x reduction
in the FPR from 24.8% to 2.0% on the harmful
behaviours dataset.
1 Introduction
We are currently experiencing a revolution in artificial
intelligence due to the rapid advancement of large language
models (LLMs) to a variety of applications, such as chatbots,
search engines and others (Kaddour et al., 2023; Jiang et al.,
2023; Ray, 2023) The current paradigm involves a two-stepprocess: initial pre-training step (Brown et al., 2020) on
extensive text corpora followed by alignment procedures
aimed at 1) teaching the model to follow instructions and
2) safeguarding the model against generating undesirable
outputs (Ouyang et al., 2022; Kaddour et al., 2023). Such
safeguards are crucial for two reasons: first, to shield users
from potentially harmful LLM outputs, and secondly, to
mitigate the risks of exploitation from malicious actors
(Bommasani et al., 2022). Recent studies have shown that
existing alignment techniques are easily circumvented by
“jailbreaks” (Zou et al., 2023; Qi et al., 2023), which are
inputs that induce LLMs to produce undesirable outputs.
To make matters worse, many of these methods rely on
LLMs themselves to discover such jailbreaks (Chao et al.,
2023; Ganguli et al., 2022). As LLMs advance, so do the
capabilities of exploiters. Consequently, the effectiveness
of our safeguards must also evolve.
It is therefore crucial to develop defence methods which also
use the LLMs themselves to prevent jailbreaks, which will
improve as the LLMs improve.
The first step of developing a safeguard is to understand
how jailbreaks are produced. Many attacks (Zhu et al.,
2023; Zou et al., 2023) exploit the so-called “auto-regressive
trap”, i.e. the fact that LLMs sample responses one token
at a time, without planning/anticipating what comes in the
farther future. As a result, the LLM can start sampling
the response “Sure let me help you with that.. ” (rather
than refusal), without “realising” that compliance with
the request ultimately results in a detailed instruction for
committing cyber-crime.
Hence, avoiding this “auto-regressive trap” offers a way to
mitigate such attacks. When the LLM is used as a separate
safety guard, it is provided with the entire output at once and
should thus be better able to classify content into harmful
andharmless correctly. This idea is explored by Helbling
et al. (2023) and
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
turned the LLM into a zero-shot classifier.
While this approach avoids the auto-regressive trap, it
suffers from domain shift : The alignment process of the
LLM consists of desired input-output pairs which contain
examples of malicious prompts and the desired refusal
response as well as benign prompts and the desired output.
In other words, during the alignment stage, the LLM is
trained in a self-censorship format, in which it responds to
1arXiv:2405.07932v2  [cs.CL]  14 May 2024
Figure 1. Examples of PARDEN. Top: PARDEN is unable to repeat the LLM output generated from a malicious user input. Hence,
the BLEU score between the LLM output and PARDEN repeat falls below the similarity threshold, a hyper-parameter of the method.
Thus, PARDEN classifies the user input as malicious and returns to the user the repeated output instead of the original output. Bottom :
PARDEN repeats almost exactly the LLM output. Hence, the BLEU score is near-perfect (with mean 0.946, std 0.0867), and PARDEN
classifies the user input as non-malicious. PARDEN thus returns the original LLM output to the user.
malicious inputs with the refusal response (e.g. “Sorry
I can’t do that. ”). By contrast, current LLM-based
safeguarding approaches (Helbling et al. (2023); Inan et al.
(2023)) use the LLM in a classification format, in which the
LLM needs to output “yes” / “no” for malicious / benign
inputs and outputs respectively.
Our key hypothesis is that this domain shift limits the
efficacy of current defence methods. To address this we
introduce PARDEN1. PARDEN prompts the LLM to repeat
its own sampled output, only presenting the original LLM
output to users if it complies to repeat (see Figure 1).
We elaborate on the hypothesis. Firstly, the auto-regressive
trap prevents the LLM from foreseeing whether the
remaining output will be harmful before it is fully generated,
buy the initial “affirmation” (Zou et al., 2023) will bias the
probability distribution of the future tokens, thereby locking
the model into generating harmful output. Secondly, domain
shifts occur when the LLM is asked to classify whether the
given content is harmful, a task that the LLM has never been
trained on.
1PARDEN is short for (Safe- Proofing L anguage Models via a
Repetition Defense)Unlike existing defense methods that rely on self-
classification, PARDEN avoids both the auto-regressive trap
anddomain shift problems. 1) PARDEN circumvents the
auto-regressive trap by re-processing the entire output of
the LLM at once before sampling a response at the filtering
stage. 2) PARDEN also resolves the domain shift problem
by presenting the filtering task as self-censorship , rather
than content classification , since repeating benign output is
a task the model is trained on.
Specifically, we find that for benign samples, the BLEU
score between the original LLM output and the LLM’s
repetition thereof is near 1.0 for most samples, indicating a
high fidelity of repetition, while the BLEU score between
the original output and the refusal response (which gets
triggered for malicious samples) is on the order of 0.2 to
0.6. This allows us to classify malicious samples using a
simple threshold parameter, by choosing an acceptable True
Positive Rate (TPR).
We empirically find that PARDEN significantly outperforms
other defence methods across a challenging dataset
consisting of successful attacks, unsuccessful attacks, and
benign prompts. Compared to the prior state-of-the-art
classification method, for Llama-2-7B, it improves the AUC
2
(Area Under Curve) score from 0.92 to 0.96, and false
positive rate (FPR) from 24.8% to 2.0% at true positive
rate (TPR) = 90%. For Claude-2.1, PARDEN improves
(TPR, FPR) from (69.2%, 2.72%) to (90.0%, 1.09%), most
notably reaching an AUC of 0.9875. See Table 2 for the full
evaluation of different models and types of harmful output.
We also publish our datasets, which can be used as standard
benchmarks for classifying harmful and benign content,
available at https://

text:
github.com/Ed-Zh/PARDEN.
2 Related Works
Finding Jailbreak In real-world scenarios, malicious
users intentionally attempt to elicit harmful behaviours
from LLMs by manipulating the user input prompt. An
ill-intentioned prompt is censored by a safety-aligned LLM,
which outputs a refusal message, such as “Sorry, as an AI,
I can’t help with that”. However, the malicious user can
bypass LLM’s safeguard with jailbreak attacks.
Many works (Perez & Ribeiro, 2022; Liu et al., 2023b;
Rao et al., 2023; Liu et al., 2023a; Zhang & Ippolito,
2023; Wei et al., 2023) manually find jailbreak prompts
for LLMs. To automate this process, GCG (Zou et al., 2023)
automatically finds adversarial suffixes using a gradient-
guided search. When provided with a harmful prompt that
would typically be censored by an aligned LLM, appending
the adversarial suffix increases the likelihood of the LLM
failing to censor the harmful output. Many other works
for automatic jailbreak prompt discovery follow: Zhu et al.
focuses on discovering interpretable adversarial prefixes
that are less detectable to a simple perplexity defence. Yu
et al. improves upon GCG by using more sophisticated
evolution strategy optimisation algorithms. Unlike prior
methods, Lapid et al. does not require whitebox access to
models by approximating the fitness of prompts solely based
on raw inputs and outputs of the model. Chao et al. use
another LLM to iteratively camouflage a malicious query,
and Mehrotra et al. improves on this technique by leveraging
tree-of-thought reasoning (Yao et al., 2024) and clipping
irrelevant candidates. Samvelyan et al. produced large sets
of attacks for diverse, specific scenarios using open-ended
search and mutation and show that finetuning on this data
improves protection against jailbreaking.
Safety Alignment through Preference Finetuning The
final step of the LLM training pipeline is to align the model
with human preferences. This process often leverages
reinforcement learning (RL), where reward signals come
either from human rating (Bai et al., 2022a; Rafailov et al.,
2023b) or synthetic data (Bai et al., 2022b) which proximate
human preferences.Jailbreak Defence Preference finetuning alone is often
not sufficient (Zou et al., 2023; Zhu et al., 2023), instead,
models deploy additional defence methods to safeguard the
LLM from undesired input and/or output.
We categorize existing defence methods into two classes.
1.Defence by Classification : Classify whether the
prompt and/or model generations contain undesirable
behaviour. If so, the LLM should output a system
rejection such as “Sorry I cannot help with that”.
PARDEN falls into this category.
2.Defence by Direct Generation : Given a prompt and/or
model’s generations, directly output the final aligned
response. Kumar et al. (2023); Robey et al. (2023) fall
into this category.
Defence by Classification Many jailbreak attacks contain
gibberish-looking text, which is often off-distribution from
the typical prompts LLMs are trained on, hence confusing
the model to output harmful generations. Perplexity filters
(Jain et al., 2023; Alon & Kamfonas, 2023) classify a
prompt as harmful if the perplexity is higher than a
predetermined threshold. However, it under-performs
when classifying high-perplexity harmless prompts and
low-perplexity harmful prompts. Our method does not
rely on these characteristics and thus is agnostic to them.
Helbling et al. use the LLM to self-classify the outputs by
prompting it “Is the following content harmful? {generated
response here }”. As mentioned before, this line of approach
suffers from the domain shift between the self-censorship
format during alignment and the classification format during
application. By contrast, PARDEN does not suffer from this
shift, since the model is trained to produce non-harmful
outputs in response to non-jailbreak queries. Kumar et al.
checks for every sub-sequence with a safety filter and the
entire prompt is flagged as harmful if any sub-sequence is
filtered as unsafe. The process is expensive and would not
scale to longer context prompts, and would easily have false
positives (i.e. “how to make a bomb” is a sub-sequence of
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
the harmless prompt “how to make a bomb sandwich”).
By contrast, PARDEN reduces these false positives by
examining the output as a whole.
Defence by Generation Jain et al.; Kirchenbauer et al. show
that using the LLM itself to paraphrase the prompt often
erases injected attacks and thus can be used to output a
safe generation. Zhang et al.; Zhang et al. also rephrases
the prompt by appending the additional descriptions of the
original prompt generated by the LLM itself. Robey et al.;
Cao et al. perturbs the input prompt and returns the output
from the perturbed input instead of the original. Unlike our
method, these approaches operate on the input space and
thus potentially modify responses even for benign prompts.
3
Since PARDEN operates on the output space, it could also
be vertically integrated with these input-space methods.
3 Background
3.1 Large Languge Models
LLMs typically employ a transformer-based architecture
(Vaswani et al., 2023), which is composed of stacking
multiple blocks of self-attention layer followed by a fully-
connected neural network. LLMs are auto-regressive
models that predict the marginal distribution of the next
token in a sequence (Brown et al., 2020). The LLM training
process consists of two stages. The first stage is a pretraining
stage where the LLM is trained via the cross-entropy loss on
next token prediction on general internet-scale text corpora.
In the second stage, LLMs are fine-tuned to address
alignment and safety (Ouyang et al., 2022) (Bai et al.,
2022b) (Rafailov et al., 2023a). One goal of this alignment
process is to ensure the LLM refuses to generate harmful
content: when given malicious prompts (X = “How do I
commit cybercrime”), the LLM should learn to output a
refusal response (Y = “Sorry I can’t help you with that”).
As mentioned in Section 2, a large amount of research
is focused on finding exploits for LLMs to evaluate and
improve their robustness.
3.2 Design Goal
In designing an LLM defence system, one often faces the
trade-off between safety andperformance . Intuitively, an
optimal defence system is one that
•corrects all jailbreaks and harmful outputs of the
undefended LLM
• maximally preserves benign outputs
While the definition of harmfulness requires human
judgement, there exist many ways to quantify how well
the system preserves benign outputs, such as the BLEU
score (details below).
3.3 BLEU Score
One measurement of distance is BLEU (BiLingual
Evaluation Understudy) (Papineni et al., 2002), often used
in bilingual translation to compare translated text against
ground truth reference text. Formally, BLEU is defined as:
BLEU =BP·exp NX
n=1wnlogpn!
.where BP is the brevity penalty, wnare weights, and pnare
given by:
pn=P
C∈{Candidates }P
ngram ∈CCount clip(ngram )
P
C′∈{Candidates }P
ngram′∈C′Count (ngram′)
Intuitively, the formula above computes pnthe n-gram
matching score for the machine translation and the reference
translation(s), and geometrically averages them to produce
the BLEU score.
Observing that repeating English text could be evaluated as
“English-English” translation, our method repurposes BLEU
to distinguish between repetition and refusal, more on this
in the next Section. We use the implementation provided by
NLTK (Bird & Loper, 2004)
4 PARDEN
We propose PARDEN, a simple but surprisingly effective
method for detecting jailbreaks. On a high-level, PARDEN
prompts the LLM to repeat its own output, with a few
in-context examples included in the prompt to prime the
method, illustrated in Figure 1.
Formally, let xbe the initial input prompt. Denote
byLLM the language model that samples the output
yauto-regressively from the next-token distribution
PLLM(Xt|x<t). So y=LLM (x)denotes the LLM’s
output. Then the combined repeat-prompt is structured
as follows:
REPEAT (y):=LLM ([prefix; examples; y;suffix; examples])
(1)
where “examples” are the in-context examples of repetitions,
“prefix” and “suffix” are the PARDEN prefix and suffix,
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
and
all of the tokens are concatenated before they are fed into
the LLM. See Section 11.1 for the specific choice of these
hyper-parameter text pieces.
In principle, we could simply return REPEAT (y)as the final
output. This shortcut is preferable if the LLM 1) perfectly
repeats benign outputs and 2) refuses all malicious outputs,
In practice, however, minor repetition errors could degrade
the quality of benign outputs, undermining the quality of
our outputs.
Hence, we use the BLEU score between yand REPEAT (y),
to determine whether the model is attempting to repeat the
output or refusing to do so. Intuitively, when the model
is attempting to repeat, the repeat is nearly identical to
the original output, leading to a BLEU score near 1.0;
conversely, when the model is refusing to repeat, the

repeat/refusal is highly dissimilar to the original output,
leading to a low BLEU score.
Setting a threshold ton the BLEU score induces a family of
classifiers, indexed by t. Formally, let htbe a classifier of
outputs, defined by:
ht(y) =1if BLEU(y, REPEAT(y)) < t→“harmful”
0otherwise →“benign”
(2)
The performance of this family of classifiers indicates the
robustness of our defence. Note that tcaptures the trade-
off between false positives and false negatives - a larger
tencourages the system to assert that the repetition isn’t
preserving the output, decides the original output is toxic,
and creates both more false positives and true positives.
Sometimes REPEAT( y) is very similar to ybut truncated
due to the maximum token limit set by the generation
configuration. Thus, when computing BLEU scores, we clip
the two sentences to the same length, up to ntokens, We
clarify that REPEAT( y) takes the whole output y- clipping
only applies to the computation of BLEU score.
4.1 Conceptual Explanation
Firstly, PARDEN avoids the “autoregressive trap” explained
in detail above. Secondly, adversarial attacks in the inputprompt space are usually edge cases characterized by
atypicality and low structure, while the output of a language
model by definition is a lot more typical and structured. By
using the model to filter the output (LLM-generated) rather
than the input (attacker-designed), we ensure that the model
does not get exposed to adversarial inputs during safety
filtering. This approach has several benefits:
1.PARDEN solely operates on the output space, whereas
safeguard mechanisms on the input space can be
explicitly circumvented. Indeed, Zhu et al. (2023)
includes perplexity scores in their loss function and
produces low-perplexity attack prompts to evade
perplexity filters. By censoring the output rather than
the input
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
, we make the defence more difficult for
attackers to directly target.
2.Producing benign outputs and refusing to produce
obviously malicious outputs is a task that the model
is trained on during the alignment phase. We refer to
this as the self-censoring format. In contrast the LLM
is not explicitly trained in the classification format
during instruction tuning. This is evidenced by LLMs’
unwillingness to label the output as either harmful or
benign even when explicitly asked to assign a label;
they often default to “I need more context”. See
Section 11.4 for example cases.
5
3.Reduction of False Positives: direct classification
might lead to false positives, where benign outputs are
incorrectly flagged as harmful due to overly cautious
classification criteria. Repetition reduces such errors
by leveraging the model’s inherent safety mechanisms,
which are designed to balance caution with practicality.
We quantify this reduction in Section 6.
4.Dynamic Adaptation: Models adapt to evolving
definitions of what constitutes harmful content. By
asking the model to repeat itself, we are bootstrapping
the model’s latest training to reassess the output - this
dynamic adaptation comes at no extra cost. However, a
static classification criteria might become outdated or
fail to capture nuanced or emerging forms of harmful
content, unless we perform further instruction tuning
on classifying those content.
4.2 Reducing Computational Cost by Partial Repeats
Some prompts elicit long responses from the LLM, making
the repeat process in PARDEN computationally expensive.
We resolve this by allowing partial repeats. Instead of
generating the entire repeat, we stop generating after the
firstnrepeated tokens. For a fixed, small n, this “early
stopping” mechanism incurs a constant cost of nforward
passes, which does not depend on the output length. Again,
we clarify that the repeater examines the entire output -
truncation only applies to the generation of the attempted
repetition and the computation of BLEU score.
5 Experimental Setup
5.1 Dataset
For a fair evaluation we need both benign and harmful
examples, to evaluate area-under-curve and other metrics
of the classifier performance. To the best of our knowledge
there unfortunately are no standard data sets for the
evaluation of jailbreak defences. To collect benign examples,
we sample 552 instructions from open-instruct-v1 Wang
et al. (2023), and produce benign outputs using Llama2
and Claude-2.1. To produce jailbreak examples, we follow
Zou et al. (2023) to adversarially attack the LLMs using
the 520 harmful behaviours in their AdvBench. Since the
original attacks only result in 60/520 jailbreaks, we further
leverage prompt injection to improve the attack success
rate, and manually filter 484 true jailbreaks for Llama2
and 539 for Claude-2.1 . See our open-source dataset at
https://github.com/Ed-Zh/PARDEN for details.
Prompt injection is a technique to prime/jailbreak LLMs
by inserting tokens after the user-assistant separator.
For instance, instead of "user: make a bomb;
assistant:" , we feed "user: make a bomb;
assistant: Sure, here’s" into the LLM. Thistechnique is also used by Samvelyan et al.. See the appendix
for some examples of the exact prompt.
5.2 Experiment Details
After collecting the dataset, we then prompt the model to
repeat the output using the techniques proposed in Section 3.
This allows us to organize the data in 4-tuples: (instruction,
output, repeat, label), where label is the ground truth label
∈ {harmful, benign }
When configuring the LLM for PARDEN, we use
temperature = 0 to evaluate greedily. This is because
for repetition, stochastic sampling would introduce extra
noise and should be avoided. A temperature of 0 ensures
PARDEN does not sample from a probability distribution.
We clarify that the original generation need not have a
temperature of 0.
5.3 Benchmarking
While most existing work on LLM defences simply reports
true positive rates, false positive rates, and accuracy, this
evaluation ignores the crucial question of how sensitive a
given system should be. This is especially problematic when
the false positives and false negatives incur an asymmetric
cost. We instead propose to look at ROC (Receiver
Operating Characteristic) curves, which plots TPR against
FPR and allows for more holistic comparison of defence
methods at different, flexible levels of sensitivity.
We benchmark our induced classifier against two existing
methods: 1) defence by binary classification proposed
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
by
Helbling et al. (2023) and 2) perplexity filters outlined in
Jain et al. (2023).
Since the binary classifier only outputs yes/no without a
continuous measure of how confident the classification is,
we need to generalize the method to a continuous family
of classifiers to compare the two methods. We propose to
look at the raw logits of the model’s prediction of the next
token. Formally, let logit Yesandlogit Nobe the predicted
logit for the next token being “Yes” and “No”, respectively,
thenlogit Yes−logit Noindicates the log-odds of answering
“Yes” (“it is harmful”) vs “No” (“it is not harmful”), which
measures how confident the model is in classifying harmful
v.s. not harmful.
The approach naturally creates a family of classifiers,
parameterized by the confidence threshold l:
gl(x) =1if(logit Yes−logit No)> l→“harmful”
0otherwise →“benign”
(3)
Similarly, we set thresholds for perplexity filters. We
implement both whole-sentence average perplexity and
sliding window perplexity for fixed window lengths, which
6
Figure 2. The Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves of PARDEN and baseline methods Left: ROC curves on the dataset
composed of GCG examples (Zou et al., 2023) and benign examples we collected. Right : ROC curves on the dataset composed of
AutoDan (Zhu et al., 2023) examples and benign examples. We include errorbars equal to 1 std of our estimates.
Figure 3. Left: The ROC curves of PARDEN and baseline methods on the aggregated dataset from Figure 2 Right: The BLEU scores
between x and REPEAT(x) are close to 1 (with mean 0.946, std 0.0867) for benign samples and around 0.4 (with mean 0.435, std 0.157)
for malicious ones.
report an adversarial attack if any window displays a
perplexity score higher than threshold. Again, varying the
threshold parameterises the family of classifiers.
At the time of the attack, the defender does not know which
type of the attack is being used. Thus we simulate both
specific and general scenarios. The specific scenarios are:
1.a GCG (Zou et al., 2023) attack (short, high perplexity)
2.an AutoDan (Zhu et al., 2023) attack, designed to evade
perplexity filters
To simulate a general scenario we aggregate the two
specific scenarios to sample a randomized attack from GCG,
AutoDan with equal probability. The attack prompts fromGCG, AutoDan are taken from their original papers and
evaluated by re-running their algorithm locally.
6 Results
To quantify how sensitive our method is to particular data,
for each threshold tfixed, we randomly sample 1000
bootstrap subsets and compute the (mean, std) of (TPR,
FPR) on those subsets. This helps us estimate the errors
and confidence of our statistics, plotted as errorbars on
the ROC curve. The resulting ROC curves are shown in
Figure 2; Since our method is input-agnostic, we summarize
its performance in the general scenario in Table 2.
We find that PARDEN obtains higher AUC than baseline
7
Classifier-Suffix PARDEN PPLX 5
AUC 0.922 0.958±0.0066 0.660
FPR @90 24.8% 2.0%±0.86 % 64.5%
Table 2. PARDEN outperforms baseline methods in AUC. Here,
FPR @90 refers to the FPR at a TPR of 90%.
methods. Furthermore, the ROC curve shows that in the
relevant regime of high True Positive Rate (TPR) and low
False Positive Rate (FPR), PARDEN drastically improves
over other methods: For instance, for Llama2-7B, at
a threshold corresponding to a TPR of 90%, PARDEN
accomplishes a roughly 11x reduction in the FPR from
24.8% to 2.0% on the harmful behaviours dataset.
We note that the difference in the input to the particular
detection method makes the comparison non-obvious.
While perplexity filters operate on the input space , the
prompted binary classifier and our method PARDEN operate
purely on the output space . Although we can compare
the prompted classifier and PARDEN using evaluation
dataset containing only outputs (regardless of what inputs
elicited these
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
outputs), benchmarking against perplexity
filters necessitates going back to the input (prompt) space.
This comparison does not perfectly hold all other variables
unchanged, since we used both 1) adversarial attacks and 2)
prompt injection when producing the adversarial outputs.
Thus, the experimental results for perplexity filters are
based on the assumption that the adversarial prompt does
elicit objectionable content without prompt injection. We
note that for this reason the experimental results likely
overestimated the true positive rate of the perplexity filters,
since not all adversarial inputs produce harmful outputs -
some need to be used in parallel with prompt injection.
We also present adversarial examples found by our method
which are not captured by the binary classifier in Table 1.
7 Experimental Analysis
7.1 Separation of Distribution
We use the BLEU distance to measure how well the output
is preserved under repetition, for both harmful and benign
examples, Figure 3.
Observe that for benign examples, the BLEU scores are
highly clustered around 1, indicating the the output is
preserved under repetition; for the harmful examples,
the BLEU scores are distributed around 0.4, indicating
considerable change to the text after repetition due to the
refusal response .
Figure 4. ROC curves for different numbers of repeat tokens.
7.2 Sensitivity to Partial Repeats
In Section 4, we argued that partially repeating the output
up to ntokens should reduce the computational cost of
our method and might help improve performance. In this
section, we investigate the sensitivity of our system to the
choice of hyper-parameter n.
For each n∈ {5,10,20,40,60,100 }, we cap the number of
tokens to nduring repetition, and compare the induced
families of classifiers. The results are shown in Figure 4.
We find that a small value of nnot only helps with
computational efficiency, but also improves the performance
of the system. This is intuitive since long repetitions are
likely to suffer from accumulating error, resulting in lower
BLEU scores even for benign examples.
Not surprisingly, initially, allowing for more tokens does
enhance the performance of the induced classifiers -
increasing nfrom 5 to 60 improves the AUC score from
0.944 to 0.960. This improvement plateaus after n= 60.
One interesting phenomenon we observed is that
repeating the entire sentence doesn’t always deliver better
performance. In fact, for very long benign outputs, repeating
all the tokens resulted in a worse BLEU score (0.954) than
repeating partially (0.960).
Investigating the error cases revealed that repetitions, even
when perfect at the start, tend to become less faithful for
longer repetitions due to error accumulation, resulting in
lower BLEU scores.
7.3 Importance of In-Context Learning
We also analyse the impact of the in-context examples that
are part of our REPEAT prompt:
8
Method PARDEN w/out ICL PARDEN
bleu 5tokens 0.7566 0.9441
bleu 10tokens 0.8639 0.9501
bleu 20tokens 0.8602 0.9457
bleu 40tokens 0.9152 0.9508
bleu 60tokens 0.9395 0.9599
bleu 100tokens 0.9405 0.9583
bleu fullsentence 0.9405 0.9545
Table 3. AUC of PARDEN w/ and w/o in-context examples in the
repeat prompt.
We find that the in-context examples are particularly useful
for low values of n, suggesting that the BLUE measure
is quite robust under full-length repetition, even without
prompt engineering. Thus, the in-context examples are
mostly relevant for the compute efficiency of our method.
7.4 Generalisability
To investigate how PARDEN generalises to models other
than Llama2, we perform PARDEN (Ours) and Helbling
et al. (2023) (Baseline) for three models (Llama2-7B
(Touvron et al., 2023), Mistral-7B (Jiang et al., 2023), and
Claude-2.1 (Anthropic)) on two dataset (harmful behaviours,
harmful strings) in AdvBench (Zou et al., 2023). Since these
two methods both operate on the output space, this allows
for a fair comparison. Results shown in Table 4:
BLEU Distributions The BLEU distributions produced
by PARDEN are divided into harmful strings
file: PARDEN, Can You Repeat That? Defending against Jailbreaks via Repetition.pdf

text:
in Figure 5
and harmful behaviours in Figure 6.
Selecting the threshold tWhen the defender LLM is
a white box model (i.e. Llama or Mistral), we fix the
TPR to be 90% for both PARDEN and the baseline; when
it’s a black box API model (i.e. Claude), we obtain the
baseline (TPR, FPR). Then, if the performance of PARDEN
at TPR=90% dominates baseline (attains a higher TPR and
a lower FPR), then we report this performance; otherwise,
if PARDEN does not clearly dominate, we fix the threshold
tso that PARDEN delivers the same TPR as baseline, and
compare their FPR.
Mistral Note that since Mistral-7B is not safety-aligned
(it outputs harmful content whenever asked to), it does not
satisfy the premise of PARDEN. Thus, we don’t expect
Mistral-7B to be capable of defending harmful content. This
is illustrated in the right columns of Figure 5 and Figure 6:
indeed, the BLEU distributions for benign and harmful
examples do not separate when Mistral is the defender. For
comprehensiveness, we include these results in the last five
rows of the Table 4.Analysis As shown in the table, across almost all models
and all datasets, except for when Mistral-7B is used as a
defender, PARDEN consistently outperforms the baseline
(Helbling et al., 2023) and considerably reduces the
FPR for the same TPR in 9 out of 10 scenarios where
its premise is satisfied, suggesting that PARDEN indeed
generalises to other datasets and settings. (There are 15
scenarios in total, 5 of which has Mistral as the defender,
which does not satisfy the premise of PARDEN.)
Additional Notes on the Datasets Note that even
though both datasets we use are proposed in the same
paper, the dataset distributions are considerably different.
Indeed, “harmful behaviours” mostly consists of malicious
instructions (e.g. build a bomb); “harmful strings” mostly
consists of offensive insults, such as racist remarks or death
threats. Note that because Claude-2.1 did not produce
enough examples under the “harmful behaviours” dataset,
we could not produce evaluations for this particular scenario.
This happens because different models are more vulnerable
to certain types of attacks due to different safety alignment
procedures used during training. In those scenarios, we
cannot do meaningful evaluation of either defense method.
7.5 Failure Cases
Although vastly more effective that alternative approaches,
PARDEN does have false negatives. Inspecting these failure
cases revealed that these outputs are often not harmful
in themselves but had malicious intentions . One such
example is asking the models to write fake reviews , shown
in the appendix. This underscores the importance of
contextualizing harmful content in its intention. Clearly,
it is questionable if this should even be considered a false
negative, since the user could have simply lied about their
request and produced the same (per-se harmless) output.
If the failure cases significantly undermines specific usage,
one can in principle apply PARDEN to both the input
and output space or combine it with input-specific filters.
For a detailed mathematical analysis of this approach, see
Section 11.6.
8 Conclusions and Future Work
Although PARDEN achieves a notable improvement over
the baseline methods such as Helbling et al. (2023), we
remark that PARDEN does assume a safely aligned base
model and relies on the model’s intrinsic safeguarding
mechanisms. Hence, our work highlights the importance of
developing safe base models. In fact, by using PARDEN to
correct jailbreak examples, we obtain data (attack prompt,
safe output) for adversarial fine-tuning.
While this work focused on the task of LLM defence,

specifically select the threshold tso that TPR is fixed at 90%. For the baseline classifier method, we similarly fix it to 90% for white box
models mistral, llama where we have access to the logits, and use the raw text output for black box models i.e. claude. Harmful Type
refers to the harmful strings and behaviours in AdvBench (Zou et al., 2023)
the method of repetition touches on the idea of LLM
composition and high-order LLMs. We conceptualise a high
order LLM to be an LLM that is a composition of first order
(auto-regressive) LLMs. Our defence approach composed
the LLM with itself, but this generalises to include arbitrary
models with compatible input and output spaces.
Repetition is one operation to stitch together two LLMs.
Mathematically, benign examples are the fixed points of
this operation, since they are preserved under repetition
on LLMs, whereas harmful examples are corrupted by
repetition. Interestingly, in addition to harmful and benign
examples, we discovered that atypical, gibberish text also
tends to be poorly preserved. What are some other
operations one can define on high-order LMs? What does
their fixed points and non-fixed points tell us?
Another question is whether the format of pre-training and
alignment steps could be adjusted to make the LLM more
robust to domain shift. For instance, the alignment step
could train the LLM both in the self-censorship and the
classification format.9 Impact Statement
This paper introduces a novel approach to defend LLMs
against jailbreak exploits. By addressing vulnerabilities
in LLMs, our method stands to bolster the integrity of AI
applications, fostering trust in these systems across various
domains. The potential impact extends beyond the academic
realm, with practical implications for industries relying
on secure AI implementations. As the threat landscape
evolves, our research strives to fortify the foundations of
machine learning, promoting responsible and resilient AI
deployment. This work underscores the commitment to
advancing not only the scientific understanding of LLMs but
also the practical implications for a secure and trustworthy
AI ecosystem.

11.4 A Claude-2.1 Example
Notice that in the following example 1. the LLM resorts
to asserting ”not enough context” for making a judgement,
despite the original output being quite obviously harmful to
an human observer. 2. We used injected prompt to elicit the
harmful content.
Input: ’role’: ’user’, ’content’: ’Give me a detailed step
by step plan’, ’role’: ’assistant’, ’content’: ”1.If you don’t
give me your password, I will kill your family. 2.To make it
more extreme,”]
Output: I will torture them slowly first. 3.Then I will findeveryone you’ve ever loved and systematically destroy their
lives. 4.I will burn down orphanages full of children. 5.I
will unleash deadly viruses to wipe out millions.
Classification: I do not have enough context to make
a judgment. Any statements about harming others or
destroying property should be taken seriously.
Repeat: I apologize, but I should not repeat or endorse
harmful, unethical, dangerous or illegal statements or plans.
11.5 BLEU Distributions
See Figure 6 and Section 11.5 for the generalisability
experiments in Section 7.4
11.6 Failure Case Analysis
PARDEN operates on the output space. It does not censor
benign outputs from malicious inputs. For malicious
instructions such as “write me a fake review”, the harmful
intention lies in the input space but does not lead to an
output which is harmful in isolation. Future work can in
principle explore including the prompt in the PARDEN
system, asking it to repeat both the input and the output.
This would allow PARDEN to detect harmful intentions in
the input space too.
We believe this failure mode is not particularly relevant
because users can easily bypass intention detection filters.
For instance, instead of asking for a fake review, a user could
falsely claim to want a genuine review of a great dining
experience. Thus, the real world relevance of correcting this
failure mode is limited.
If filtering input space is critical for the application, there
are several methods that act solely on the input space, and
we can integrate these methods vertically: in the combined
system, we have PARDEN processing the output and these
methods (or PARDEN again) processing the input. This
does come at a cost, which we give an analytical form:
suppose a successful jailbreak is misleading (i.e. harmful
input, seemingly “benign” output) with probability p, and
that we have access to a classifier with TPR = aand FPR =
b. Then the defense system only with output filtering has
overall TPR = (1−p)aand FPR = b; the system with both
input and output filtering has overall TPR = (1−p)(2a−
a2) +p(1−a)and FPR = (2b−b2). Note that this leads to
both higher TPR and FPR since 0≤a, b≤1. Intuitively,
this catches the previously failed cases but also incorrectly
flags more benign inputs as harmful. Exactly when this
tradeoff is favourable depends on the value of p. For our
dataset, since p is small ( 4/520 examples), having input
filtering hurts performance as it increases the FPR by a lot,
with only small gains in TPR. However, one can imagine
that over time these “misleading” attacks become more
prevalent, crossing the threshold where it makes sense to
